thread.title: Why The Jolly Roger Did Not Raise In The 2015 Playoffs
thread.title_full: Why The Jolly Roger Did Not Raise In The 2015 Playoffs

author: Brandon Arroyo
title: Why The Jolly Roger Did Not Raise In The 2015 Playoffs
text:
Why The Jolly Roger Did Not Raise In The 2015 Playoffs Posted: BArroyo@wicu12.com 
PITTSBURGH, PA (WICU-WSEE) -- Here we go again, who is to blame? 
Two aces on that PNC Park mound, win or go home scenario for the NL Wild Card spot for the second year in a row. For the second year in a row, the Pirates get offensively handcuffed and pitched out of the playoffs. 
Cole vs Arrieta was the prime time matchup we heard about days on end, but is it that surprising that the Cubs 'rocket arm' dominated? 
While offensively the Pirates lost their rookie stand out Jung Ho Kang to a knee injury in mid-September, the Buccos were still 11-5 to finish the year, and finished with the second highest win total in the MLB. 
No, this was about the second straight year of a pitcher coming into Pittsburgh red hot and throwing a career season. In 2015, that pitcher is Jake Arrieta. 
The 29-year old right hander from Farmington, Missouri, is on a record setting tear. Since the All-Star break, Arrieta has pitched MLB record-low, 0.75 ERA. 
Against the Pirates, that success has been season long. Of the 16-Pirates to face Arrieta this year, only three have scored. Only two batted over .200. 
As the 6'4" Chicago ace watched his offense take a 3-0 lead in the bottom of the third, the Cubs could all but order their tickets to Saint Louis. The Chi-Town baby bears have finished the 2015 season 16-0 with a three-run lead and Arrieta on the mount. 
Gerrit Cole's struggles against Dexter Fowler didn't help their cause either. 
Coming into this NL Matchup, Dexter Fowler had more experience facing Gerrit Cole than any other Chicago Cub this season. 12-times they had faced off in the regular season (3 hits, and 3 strike outs). That familiarity payed major dividends Wednesday night, the center fielder accounted for three hits, three runs, and a homer in his first three at bats. 
In the top of the 4th inning in 2014, the Giants Brandon Crawford launched an Edinson Volquez pitch to the deep seats. That shot, was one the Pirates could not recover from. 
As Kyle Schwarber sent a two-run shot in the third, Buccos fans begrudgingly showed an exasperated look on their collected face that read, "not again". 
Just as the Buccos received a quick ticket out of the playoffs in 2014 to the tune of an 8-0 shut-out, the post-season Jolly Roger remained unraised in 2015 courtesy of a 4-0 shut out. 
The Pirates have the stars, they have the talent. However, much like the Detroit Pistons in the 1990s, they have matched up against historic talent, that is in their prime, in the worst possible situation. 
The only difference is in this situation, rather than running into Michael Jordan, Pirates run into Madison Bumgarner and Jake Arrieta. 
####
